div1.head: Jim to Mademoiselle Marcelle Guerin June 13th 1916
div1.p:
It seems years since we’ve done anything. The weather has been so bad. The other morning, it was Saturday, a Boche was signaled over Vaux, and I happened to be on guard, so I had the delightful job of flirting with the clouds looking for him. I could see no machine so kept on into German territory. It looked very calm and peaceful back there. After twenty minutes I thought it best to turn and go
towards home. It seemed ages before Verdun came to view beneath a hole in the clouds. There is a broad brown band north of Verdun which marks the territory where the fighting has taken place. It does not seem of this earth. At each side are shell holes but in the brown band there are none to be seen. They are so numerous that they blend into each other. What trees there were have all gone, and if villages were there, there is no
sign of them left. Even the broad white roads have vanished as if erased from a blackboard. Beneath one there are flashes as if one turned on a pocket lamp. And the machine rocks. Soon there is a puff of smoke when the projectile explodes. That’s as much as we see of a battle. The motor drowns all other sounds and we see but the flash and smoke. The battle seems quiet and still. It is very weird. To see the endless fall of
shells makes one wonder how men can stand in the face of such fire. There is a haze above Mort Homme — so thick is the smoke. But its all silent. Its queer that. Then away on the other side of the lines a squadron of Boche planes goes by. Above are little black specks. They are the guarding Fokkers. One watches and forgets the fight below for one’s sphere is the air and there will be something coming out of it before long.
And all that passes in silence and one is lonely.

Kiffin told me to day that you and your mother had come to see him when he was in Paris. He told me that you were entrancing. His description was vague but please remember the combination you had for I want to see you dressed in that way. Not that you are not always entrancing but your “get up” that
day was something very extra from all accounts.

I suppose you have received my last letter from here. I’ve been hoping to receive news of you ever since I left Luxeuil. It won’t be much more that two months before I am allowed a “permission”. I’m looking forward to that with delight.
You’ll see Lovell before long. He’s leaving soon.

Paul writes me that he’s passed several very delightful times with you. Great to be all in a little family like that. Betty is back in Paris, as you probably know, and seems quite normal in her letters. She says no one would know she had been sick. I wonder if she
does not yet know about the accident.
Do let me hear from you Marcelle.
